public-advisory.Headline: Rushing water conditions – USE EXTREME CAUTION
public-advisory.Description: The access trail leading into Evanoff Provincial Park, to Fang Trailhead, crosses a creek. The current water levels are high; it is not advised to cross during high or rushing water conditions. Visitors are urged to use extreme caution when crossing this creek, or consider to reschedule their visit for another time.

public-advisory.Headline: Access to Lake Lovely Water trailhead
public-advisory.Description: Access is from the west side of the Squamish River. The east side of the river is First Nations land and BC Parks does not recommend using the dirt road to access the trailhead due to land use issues. Use of the cable car is also PROHIBITED. Helicopter and boat services are available, see the Location section below for further details.

public-advisory.Headline: Blackwall Road and Lone Duck 1 Shelter winter closures
public-advisory.Description:
Blackwall Road to the Cascade Lookout and Alpine Meadows is now closed for the season to vehicle traffic due to snow.

Lone Duck 1 shared winter shelter will not be open this year due to COVID-19.

public-advisory.Headline: Campground and park gate closed for the winter
public-advisory.Description:
Rolley Lake Campground and park main gate are closed for the winter. No vehicle access to park, but foot traffic is welcome. Overnight camping is not permitted. Winter camping is available nearby at Golden Ears Provincial Park.

Rolley Lake Campground and main gate will reopen on April 1, 2021.
See dates of operation.

public-advisory.Headline: Golden Ears Provincial Park winter hours
public-advisory.Description:
Golden Ears Provincial Park is now operating on winter hours. The park gate is open 8am - 5:30pm daily, please exit the park by 5:30pm. If hazardous road conditions exist (snow/ice on road), the park gate will remain closed all day. Winter camping is available at Gold Creek Campground when the park road is open.
See dates of operation. For updates on road conditions and closures, visit the Park Operator’s Twitter feed @alouetteparks

public-advisory.Headline: Tote Road and Stillwater Lake Trail Conditions Update
public-advisory.Description:
Due to 2017 wildfire activity, significant flood risk hazard and debris flow hazard exists at drainages along the Tote Rd. Park visitors should avoid travelling on the Tote Rd during high water or rain events.

Due to rockfall on the Tote Road, it is driveable only by 4x4 high clearance vehicles with narrow wheelbase.

Stillwater lake trail is open.

public-advisory.Headline: Temporary noise and trail closures
public-advisory.Description: Park visitors may expect some minor noise disturbance and traffic flow delays as a fuel management treatment project is being carried out. For the safety of the public, some trails may also be temporarily closed while this activity is taking place.

public-advisory.Headline: Expect winter snow conditions at higher elevations (>1300m) all across Garibaldi Park
Cheakamus campground flooding
public-advisory.Description: Cheakamus campground is currently experiencing flooding due to heavy rain. Two of the eight campsites are covered in water.

public-advisory.Headline: Traffic pattern change at Manson’s Landing Oct. 16, 2020
public-advisory.Description:
In order to protect the sensitive coastal sands ecosystems at Manson’s Landing Park, the rock barriers that prevent vehicle access to the spit will be relocated. The barriers will be moved approximately, 80m South toward the boat launch turn around area . Please use the boat launch with care. Assist restoration efforts by parking vehicles and trailers in the parking area opposite the government dock, once you have finished launching your boat.

The rock barriers will be relocated on October 16, 2020. Please note, boat launch access will be limited while the work is being completed. Thank-you for your cooperation.

public-advisory.Headline: Day-use passes are not required to visit the park at this time
Picnic Shelter remains closed for the season

public-advisory.Description:
Due to a problem bear in the area, Botanical Beach remains closed for public safety. BC Parks is closely monitoring and assessing the activity and behaviour of the bear. The closure is reassessed daily and Botanical Beach will be open as soon as possible.

public-advisory.Description: Be cougar smart and keep your pets on leash.

public-advisory.Description: Starting in 2015, off-road vehicle registration is mandatory on crown land, including on forest service roads. Find out more at: Off-Road Vehicle Management Framework.

public-advisory.Headline: Bear Advisory – updated September 14, 2020 and ongoing
public-advisory.Description:
BC Parks has received ongoing reports of bear observations in San Josef Bay Area and along the North Coast Trail. All visitors and hikers in Cape Scott must be extremely mindful about how they recreate in bear habitat to help prevent bears from becoming habituated to humans and conditioned to insecure attractants.

Please do your part when recreating in bear country and help keep bears wild.

  • More about wildlife safety
  • More about backcountry etiquette

If you encounter an aggressive wild animal, report it by calling the Conservation Officer Service 24-hour hotline toll free at 1-877-952-7277 (RAPP) or #7277 on the Telus Mobility Network.

public-advisory.Headline: Trail and recreational access closures this fall
public-advisory.Description:
Trail and recreational access closures this fall

Please be advised that BC Parks will be conducting three fuel management projects in West Arm Park this fall (September to December). To ensure public safety during these treatments, there will be trail closures and recreational access closures associated with all three projects.

  1. 12.7 hectare hand treatment 1km up Svoboda Road in the vicinity of Short Svoboda, Frog Jam, Squeeler, and Toe Jam Trails. Expect trail closures from September 8th until late November or early December. Please also see trail information on the Nelson Cycling Club’s Facebook page.
  2. 12.7 hectare hand treatment along Lasca Road. There will be no recreational access beyond the gate as of September 1st until late November or early December.
  3. 15.4 hectare mechanical treatment at the end of Lasca Road. There will be no recreational access beyond the gate as of September 1st until late November or early December.

Please obey all informational signage posted on site and please check this website often for the latest updates.

For more information please call 250 489-9211.

public-advisory.Headline: New campsites and accessibility improvements at Loveland Bay Provincial Park
public-advisory.Description:
In response to public demand for increased camping opportunities in highly desirable locations, the Provincial Government has invested $22.9 million in campgrounds throughout British Columbia over the last five years.

This includes new campsites at Loveland Bay Provincial Park. Over the next year, 22 additional campsites will be added to meet increased demand. This project will also include upgrades to the existing campsites, a reconstructed beach area, new toilet facilities, expanded parking and improved accessibility to visitors. In addition, improvements to the campground road will result in better passage for fish and amphibians.

  • Loveland Bay Campground Expansion Sign [PDF]

public-advisory.Headline: To protect both people and bears, special regulations in place during the salmon run
public-advisory.Description:
BC Parks is eagerly anticipating the return of the Kokanee salmon to the spawning channel at Kokanee Creek Park. The park has an elevated boardwalk to allow visitors to view the salmon in the spawning channel. BC Parks would like to remind visitors that during the spawning period, bears are also frequent visitors to the channel to feed on the salmon. To protect both people and bears, the spawning channel viewing areas have special regulations in place during the salmon run.

These restrictions will come into effect when the Kokanee spawning is occurring in the channel, from August 14th to October 7th, 2020 and will include:

  1. Dogs will not be permitted on the boardwalk or the trails adjacent to the spawning channel.
  2. Bicycles must be walked across the boardwalk and along the trails adjacent to the spawning channel.
  3. The portion of the spawning channel downstream of the viewing platform will be closed to the public during the period that bears are utilizing it for feeding. This closure will include the trails behind the Nature Center.
  4. Please respect the new covid-19 guidelines and traffic flow signs for the Spawning Channel trails. Wearing a mask is encouraged.

public-advisory.Headline: Campfires are not permitted in this park
White-Nose Syndrome
public-advisory.Description:
White-nose Syndrome is a fungal disease that has been linked to the mass die-off of hibernating bats in Eastern North America – it poses a significant threat to bats of the west and British Columbia. There is evidence that humans have accelerated the spread through entering caves with contaminated clothing, gear or equipment. To help prevent WNS from taking hold in B.C., the Province is making investments in bat conservation projects.

To ensure the protection of bats and their habitat in this park, BC Parks strongly advises that personal caving gear that has been used anywhere east of the Rockies not be used in B.C. Also, before entering caves in B.C, cavers and visitors should consult the provincial WNS website, which includes a link to a Decontamination Protocol for Mines and Caves.

  • Learn more about white-nose syndrome

Road and Trail Information
public-advisory.Description:
NOTICE OF INTERMITTENT ROAD CLOSURE - The Walker FSR will have intermittent delays for repairs scheduled to be completed on the Fraser River Bridge (G1-710), located at 5.3 Km. Work is scheduled to commence on August 17th, and will last approximately 7 days.

While travelling on the Walker Creek Forest Service Road (FSR), attention is required to navigate the surface as it is uneven, rutted, slippery and very rough. The road is not recommended for anything other than a 4x4, high clearance vehicle, and drivers familiar with this type of vehicle operation.

The trail between Bastille Creek and Buchanan Creek can result in quite a bit of hiking around sections where the old road surface has washed away and some travel on muddy sections of the winter snowmobile route due to ATV/UTV traffic and wet conditions up to Buchanan Creek where ATV/UTV traffic is not permitted within the boundaries of the Park. Trail/route surface is a good hard surface from Buchanan Creek to Kakwa Lake.

Visitors planning to camp overnight are asked to limit the length of their stay, and advised to make back-up plans since the campground is likely to be full.

public-advisory.Headline: Bridge removal project
public-advisory.Description: On August 17, 2020, BC Parks will be closing one section of a multi-use trail near Mt. Sullivan for a stream restoration project involving the removal of an old log bridge crossing and stabilization of the stream channel and banks. This work will address the issue of bridge material slumping into the salmon bearing creek below, negatively affecting fish habitat, clogging culverts in the lower reaches of the creek and eroding archeological sites. The trail will remain closed while BC Parks monitors the bank stabilization and determines an appropriate form and location of a new crossing. Additional stream diversion work will also be taking place upland and below the bridge site to help restore natural flows and address trail erosion issues. Minor disruptions can be expected.

public-advisory.Headline: Drinking water at Mahood Lake campground on permanent boil water order
public-advisory.Description:
Park Visitors are advised to either bring their own potable water or boil water prior to consumption. Interior Health advises the following:
  • Boiling water is the most effective way to disinfect water, particularly if you think your water has parasites such as Giardia or Cryptosporidium, or if you have a weakened immune system.
  • Boil water for at least 1 minute. At elevations over 2,000 meters (6,500 feet) boil water for at least 2 minutes.
  • Store disinfected water in clean, covered, food grade containers
BC Parks is working with Interior Health and our Capital program and hopes to develop a new drinking water source at the Park in the near future. Unfortunately this will take some time. Please consult this web page for future updates.

Please obtain a pass for the following day-use destinations: the South Beach day-use area parking lot, the Alouette Lake boat launch parking (for boat trailers), West Canyon Trailhead parking lot and the East Canyon and North Beach parking lot.

You can obtain a pass on the Discover Camping website. Passes are available starting at 6AM for a same day visit. Please have your pass ready for review by the Park Operator staff at the checkpoint on the main access road.

Vehicles that arrive at the checkpoint without a day-use pass or a camping reservation will be asked to turn around and return with a valid pass or reservation.

Please note: Passes do not guarantee a parking spot. Visitors should plan accordingly.

  • Day-Use Pass Information

public-advisory.Headline: Playground construction and trail upgrades are scheduled to start August 4 and continue through to August 21
public-advisory.Description: Expect disruption and some noise disturbance in the campground during this time. We appreciate your patience.

public-advisory.Headline: Stargazing and Aurora Borealis viewing is becoming increasingly popular at Porteau Cove
public-advisory.Description: Please note that the park is closed from 11 PM to 7 AM and stargazers must vacate the park between these hours.

public-advisory.Headline: Caution: Extreme danger due to high water
public-advisory.Description: The water level is extremely high and the creek crossings are extremely dangerous at this time. Crossing the creek is not recommended.

public-advisory.Headline: Notice of changes to camping at Smelt Bay
public-advisory.Description:
• Camping is by 100% reservation, on.
  • First-come, first-served campsites are not available.
  • Due to COVID-19, overflow is very limited at this location to ensure safe spacing between sites.

public-advisory.Headline: Please note that significant concerns around a localized outbreak of COVID-19 exist in the remote northern communities
public-advisory.Description: Visitors to Chase Provincial Park are asked to access the park from the south end via the Finlay-Osilinka Forest Service Road and refrain from entering any indigenous communities.

public-advisory.Headline: This park is closed and visitors to the area are asked to refrain from entering the community
public-advisory.Description:
Please note that significant concerns around a localized outbreak of COVID-19 exist in the remote northern community of Kwadacha Village (Fort Ware).

Services such as fuel and food supplies are not available to the general public. BC Parks appreciates the public’s cooperation in following the request of the communities and keeping members safe during these challenging times.

public-advisory.Headline: Visitors to this [pType] are asked to refrain from entering either community or mooring boats at the dock
public-advisory.Description: Please note that significant concerns around a localized outbreak of COVID-19 exist in the remote coastal communities of Lax Kw’alaams and Metlakatla. BC Parks appreciates the public’s cooperation in following the request of the communities and keeping members safe during these challenging times.

public-advisory.Headline: Canyonlands Trail Bridge Damage
public-advisory.Description: Due to damage from high water, the bridges over Trout Creek and Hemp Creek have been washed away. The rivers are impassible during normal flows. These bridges are normally accessed from the Flatiron Trail but may also be accessed via trails from Green Mountain or Moul Falls (note that the Moul Falls Trail remains open).

public-advisory.Headline: Pilot bay lighthouse facility is closed due to COVID-19 concerns. The trail is open.
The historic Peace Arch monument will be refurbished in the summer of 2020
public-advisory.Description: The work is expected to take place from July 16th to September. The work will include vapour blasting, priming, repainting, restoring inscriptions, restoring ornamental gates, and restoring the commemorative plaques. Please note the arch may not be visible during this time due to the need to wrap the structure to contain removed paint and protect the work.

public-advisory.Headline: The park is open for day-use, although the official day-use area and playground are closed due to bank erosion
Smoke from pile burning to be visible in Smithers area
public-advisory.Description:
To reduce the risk of wildfire in the Call Lake Provincial Park, the BC Wildfire Service and BC Parks will be burning piles of wood debris between July 13 and 24, 2020.

  • Information Bulletin

public-advisory.Headline: Clearwater River Trail South - change in access
public-advisory.Description: Spahats Creek footbridge out due to flood damage. Crossing the creek from the Land Bridge towards First Canyon is not possible at this time.

public-advisory.Headline: High water levels
public-advisory.Description: High water levels have flooded some parts of trails and marine campsites. Please plan accordingly and stay well back from the edge of  creeks and rivers.

public-advisory.Headline: Park Opening Announcement
public-advisory.Description:
BC Parks is very pleased to announce jointly with Xeni Gwet’in First Nation that Ts’il?os Provincial Park is open for both day-use and overnight camping, including Nu Chugh Beniz & Gwe Da Ts’ih campgrounds.

BC Parks has continued to keep the health and wellbeing of our visitors, staff, park operators, and local communities as our top priority by implementing COVID-19 safety protocols and respecting continued PHO guidelines around physical distancing,

The BC Parks Guide to Camping During COVID-19 is an excellent resource to help you understand what to expect when you arrive at the campgrounds. The guide outlines how to prepare, set up, and stay safe while visiting BC Parks.

All visitors to Ts’il?os Park are asked to be fully self-contained and to have no contact with local community members in the Nemiah Valley in order to limit the chance of spreading the COVID-19 virus. The gas station, tire repair and convenience store are closed to non-residents. Visitors are reminded to check www.xenigwetin.net for updates on access to Title Lands.

We appreciate your ongoing cooperation as we work to keep our staff, park operators, local communities, and visitors safe.

public-advisory.Headline: Mahood Lake Group Site closed until further notice
public-advisory.Description: Due to extreme flooding conditions the group site, as well as campsites 33 and 34 at Mahood Lake campground is unusable at this time.  Reservation holders for the sites will be notified and refunded their fees for camping.  BC Parks will continue to monitor the water situation and update this webpage as conditions improve.

public-advisory.Headline: Train line adjacent to park
public-advisory.Description: Park visitors should be aware of a train line which runs alongside the park. Trains can run during the early hours of the morning which can cause some noise disruption within the park.

public-advisory.Headline: Prevent raccoons from becoming food conditioned
public-advisory.Description: Secure all your belongings and do not feed the raccoons.  This [pType] has an abundant raccoon population that thrives on park visitor’s food, garbage and other scented items.

public-advisory.Headline: Construction noise
public-advisory.Description: Park visitors should be aware of an excavation project currently underway across from the park between the hours of 7am - 4pm. Minor noise and vibration disruption may occur during this time. Thanks!

public-advisory.Headline: BC Parks warns visitors to use extra caution due to high water in the Thompson River
public-advisory.Description: With all the campsites in this popular park being located along the Thompson River, and the extreme high water flows currently being experienced, BC Parks is warning our visitors to use extra caution. Extreme caution, especially with children or pets, should be exercised at this time. In some locations the river is flowing at less than a metre from the backside of campsites. Both the North and the South Thompson Rivers have peaked and extreme flows should start to subside in the next week.

public-advisory.Headline: Notice of Temporary Closure
public-advisory.Description: The eastern entrance to Cameron Lake day-use area and a section of the parking lot will be closed from July 12 to July 25, 2020 while construction work is undertaken on the eastern boundary. Please exercise caution when accessing the area via the western entry, as vehicle movement will be restricted. Please observe all signage. Thank you for your cooperation.

public-advisory.Headline: Please be aware of poor road conditions on industrial roads required to access this park
public-advisory.Description:
The roads to access this park via the Menzie’s Bay Main and the Morton Lake FSR are in poor condition.
These roads at the present time are only maintained to an industrial standard and will be very rough in some areas.

public-advisory.Headline: You are in bear country
public-advisory.Description:
• Coolers are not bear proof
  • Secure all food and attractants; unsecured attractants may result in eviction and/or fines
  • Dispose of garbage and grey water in approved receptacles
  • Never approach or feed a bear
  • Report all bear sightings

public-advisory.Description: With all the campsites in this popular park being located along the Thompson River, and the extreme high water flows currently being experienced, BC Parks is warning our visitors to use extra caution. Extreme caution, especially with children or pets, should be exercised at this time. In some locations the river is flowing at less than a metre from the backside of campsites. Both the North and the South Thompson Rivers have peaked and extreme flows should start to subside in the next week.

public-advisory.Headline: Tour buses prohibited
public-advisory.Description: Tour Buses are prohibited in this park due to COVID-19 response.

public-advisory.Headline: The Inland Lake trail may not be currently passable with all types of wheelchairs/scooters
public-advisory.Description: Trail work will be occurring and BC Parks will update this webpage once the work is completed. We appreciate your patience.

public-advisory.Headline: First loop of Hampton Campground opening July 9
public-advisory.Description: As of July 9th, the first loop of Hampton Campground (sites 1-24 and 79-100) will be open, including the playground and toilet shower building. Amenities in the remaining areas of the campground continue to be closed until further notice.

public-advisory.Headline: Muddy conditions on Bugaboo Forest Service Road
public-advisory.Description: Muddy conditions on Bugaboo Forest Service Road are preventing 2 wheel drive access to the Bugaboo trailhead. Low clearance vehicles not recommended for access to the park.

public-advisory.Headline: Klappan Rail Grade is impassible
public-advisory.Description: The Klappan Rail grade has suffered a wash out at km 30. Eaglenest Creek Trail and Didene Portage trail are no longer accessible via the Klappan Rail Grade. Access to Spatsizi Plateau Wilderness Provincial Park is possible through air charter or via the McEwan Creek Trail.

public-advisory.Headline: Cold Fish Lake Camp facilities closed for the season
public-advisory.Description: All facilities at Cold Fish Lake Camp are closed to visitors for the 2020 season. This decision has been made to ensure the continued health and safety of BC Parks visitors, employees, park contractors, volunteers and partners, and to support efforts to reduce the spread of COVID-19.

public-advisory.Headline: This park is no longer closed due to COVID-19
public-advisory.Description:
• There are no facilities, trails, or services in this park.  
    • There is no access to this park due to it being on the West side of the Squamish River.

public-advisory.Headline: Campground and boat launch closed
public-advisory.Description: The campground and boat launch at Pennask Lake Park, at the south east end of Pennask Lake, are closed until further notice due to a hazard tree issue.

public-advisory.Headline: Group campsites have been repurposed at this park
public-advisory.Description: Due to ongoing operational changes as part of our COVID-19 response, group campsites have been repurposed at this park for new family camping opportunities. Please check the COVID-19 page for the most up-to-date information.

public-advisory.Headline: Public access to the column features is not permitted
public-advisory.Description: Keremeos Columns Park does not contain the geological features that were intended to be protected at the time of establishment in the early 1930s. The column features are fully contained on private land. At this time, public access to the column features is not permitted. Viewing of the column features must be done so by using valley bottom vantage points that do not involve encroachment or access onto private land.

public-advisory.Headline: Nyrstar Mine Access
public-advisory.Description: To ensure public safety and maintain continued access through the active mine, the public is reminded to be respectful of the mine entrance "Checkpoint", obey all No Entry signs and follow directional signage to park trailheads/parking. Mine site conditions can change rapidly and industrial mine traffic is constantly active. While visitors are safe travelling through the mine along the main road corridor, there is a safety risk if deviating into No Entry areas. Thank you for your cooperation.

public-advisory.Headline: Athabasca River suspension bridge failure
public-advisory.Description: On October 1, 2014, the suspension bridge which crosses the Athabasca River in Jasper National Park, along the land access route to Hamber Park, failed.

public-advisory.Headline: Backcountry Reservations
public-advisory.Description: As of February 28, 2017, the Jedediah Island Marine Provincial Park backcountry campground offers backcountry registrations via our Discover Camping Backcountry Registration System.

public-advisory.Headline: Access road to Mortar and Pestle Trailhead is washed out
public-advisory.Description: The access road to Mortar and Pestle Trailhead is washed out and impassable by motor vehicles.
